message:
I need some advice from Virtualization experts:

I did my fair share of research and can't find some solid solution that matches what I'm looking for.

Here's some background: 
- We have a test center where every analyst works on resolving number of test cases.
- We work with a big number of software stacks. A stack is a combination of different software versions that makes for a unique environment. Sometimes, installing a Service Pack can be a big change, so it has to have its own stack.
- Each person, of course, can have only one stack on their own machine.
- We do have a vCenter/vSphere solution in place and it's pretty good but we're looking to improve.

Here's what we're trying do:
- I'd like to have one VM per stack. That VM would be installed by IT (or someone assigned to that task).
- When a support case comes in, the analyst would choose the VM that best machines their case and then creates a separate instance of that VM and give it a name related to their case number.
- This is, of course, possible in a number of ways. Templates and Clones do this.
- My idea was to use Linked Clones, they can save on disk space and they're very quick to create. However, I have number of problems with how linked clones are created in vSphere:
1- They require the user to know a lot of technical details about the VM infrastructure (similar to creating new machines). It would be safer and easier to have a specialist do the cloning (which is not convenient given the big number of VM that has to be created).
2- I'm not clear on permissions in vSphere but how can I control giving users permission to create these clones while not giving them full permissions.
- I'd like to be able to do something like: right click -> create new instance -> Enter machine name -> Done. Basically, "give me an instance of this machine", like how Vagrant works.

Any suggestions on vSphere (or VMware products) or any other vendor are welcomed.
Let me know if you have any questions

Thanks in advance!

Actualy Meligy raised a good point, are you open to cloud based solution or tied to on-premises (cost / regulations etc)?

We have a similar situation, maybe a little complex. Each customer has multiple servers, each of it's own role, stack of SW,  and connectivity options (mainly VPN solutions). We usually need to simulate their setup for testing/analysis and Amazon Web Services (AWS) has been more than enough for the job. 

What I like about this solution:
- Simple, even moderate team members can get into it w/o training.
- Accessible almost from everywhere. Even you can send someone an image/instance link w/ a user account and s/he will be ok whatever platform s/he uses
- You can create as many images (SW stack of a VM, not linked to a specific H/W) and instances (full VM) and you won't be charged for it unless used.
- Unless you are analyzing performance related cases or running really heavy SW, you'll find really cheap AWS instances that costs less than 7 cents / hr. Extra small instances running Linux are free!
- Rich set of APIs that facilitate automated testing/analysis (a small script can start a machine, launch a specific SW, run tests, send results, then shut it down)

Never, have been already over those advocacy days (u should catch me back then :)

I myself have been part of the team who set the exam objectives and wrote and reviewed the questions for MCTS - WCF and MCPD - Azure yet buried head to toe in AWS as it's my company choice now. Not advocate for any of them either

Back to main topic, I wanted to stress a fact you - and many - already know that cloud != throwing exiting infrastructure. 

Cloud is the silver bullet for every problem > so superficial, so totally agree. Yet in this case (analysis / testing) I can see the cloud as a perfect fit, at least in my experience. Some of our customers are hospitals sparse  30+ locations across US, each of it's own local server(s). Asking for even 1/3 this # of servers to replicate their environment would get me fired on the spot :) On the other side, 30 servers on AWS for an hour would cost just a few bucks

I can't argue if hybrid clouds are mature or not, it depends on your definition of maturity. Yet in my daily job, I can see some interesting situations where hybrid clouds is a life saver.

For example, in medical field, you need your gateway servers connected directly to modalities (i.e ultra sound machines). Cloud is so cumbersome and unreliable for this job. On the other side, we process a homogeneous amount of images/videos that would cost a small clinic a fortune to do on-premises. Here comes hybrid clouds.

Finally, I wasn't contributing enough here and it seems I've been missing a lot of fun actually :)
